projects.title: CinePeek
projects.description:
CinePeek is a dynamic web application designed for movie and TV show enthusiasts.

The platform is built to be intuitive and comfortable for long browsing sessions, allowing users to explore the latest popular movies and TV shows, access detailed information about individual titles, and search through an extensive database of films and series.

The design emphasizes:

Special attention is given to user experience details such as smooth navigation, predictable interactions, and readable content presentation.
The goal of the product design is to make movie exploration feel simple, engaging, and visually pleasant, without overwhelming the user with unnecessary elements.
goals: consistent spacing, typography, and color usage
clear visual hierarchy to highlight important information
responsive behavior across different screen sizes
projects.developmentDescription:
CinePeek is designed with a clear separation between presentation, state management, and data access layers.

The architecture follows a component-driven approach, where UI components remain declarative and focused on rendering, while business logic and side effects are handled outside the view layer.

The application is structured around:
developmentLayers: Presentation layer — reusable components responsible only for UI and user interactions
State layer — state management to handle global application state
Data layer — API services responsible for communication with TMDB API
projects.developmentConclusion: This separation improves maintainability, testability, and long-term scalability of the codebase.

projects.title: Pixel Play
projects.description:
Pixel Play is a 2D retro-style platformer in which the player kills enemies by collecting power-ups and scoring high scores.

The game interface is built to be intuitive and comfortable for long play sessions, featuring pixelated graphics and nostalgic gameplay reminiscent of classic arcade games.

The design emphasizes:

Special attention is given to user experience details such as smooth controls, predictable mechanics, and readable game state.
The goal of the product design is to make the game feel simple, engaging, and visually pleasant, without overwhelming the player with unnecessary elements.
goals: consistent spacing, typography, and color usage
clear visual hierarchy to highlight important information
responsive behavior across different screen sizes
projects.developmentDescription:
Pixel Play is designed with a clear separation between presentation, game logic, and rendering layers.

The architecture follows a component-driven approach, where game components remain focused on rendering and user input, while game state and logic are handled in dedicated modules.

The application is structured around:
developmentLayers: Presentation layer — Canvas rendering and UI responsible for display and user interactions
State layer — game state management for scores, player position, and enemy logic
Data layer — modular game logic and collision detection
projects.developmentConclusion: This separation improves maintainability, testability, and long-term scalability of the codebase.

projects.title: Kito
projects.description:
Kito is an anime discovery and tracking platform designed with a strong focus on clarity, usability, and visual balance.

The interface is built to be intuitive and comfortable for long browsing sessions, allowing users to explore anime titles, search content, and navigate between sections without friction.

The design emphasizes:

Special attention is given to user experience details such as smooth navigation, predictable interactions, and readable content presentation.
The goal of the product design is to make anime exploration feel simple, engaging, and visually pleasant, without overwhelming the user with unnecessary elements.
goals: consistent spacing, typography, and color usage
clear visual hierarchy to highlight important information
responsive behavior across different screen sizes
projects.developmentDescription:
Kito is designed with a clear separation between presentation, state management, and data access layers.

The architecture follows a component-driven approach, where UI components remain declarative and focused on rendering, while business logic and side effects are handled outside the view layer.

The application is structured around:
developmentLayers: Presentation layer — reusable React components responsible only for UI and user interactions
State layer — centralized state management using Redux to handle global application state
Data layer — API services responsible for communication with external and internal APIs
projects.developmentConclusion: This separation improves maintainability, testability, and long-term scalability of the codebase.
